repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
The moddict must not come from the shared module.

Add test and validation that we don't make this mistake again.

Fixes #7290

comment_data.body: I couldn't immediate spot anything else like this that looked dodgy - most other NAMED_CGLOBALs look fine to shared for example.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -823,6 +823,12 @@ def specialize(self, pyrex_type=None, **data):
 
             self.specialize_list.append(s)
             return s
+        
+    def _validate_suitable_for_sharing(self):
+        code_string = getattr(self, "impl")
+        if not code_string: return
+        assert "NAMED_CGLOBAL(moddict_cname)" not in code_string, \

comment_data.body:
Since this is an exported function that might get called via stack arguments, I suggest reordering the arguments to avoid padding due to alignment effects.

```suggestion
/////////////// ImportImpl.export ///////////////

static PyObject *__Pyx__Import(PyObject *name, PyObject *const *imported_names, Py_ssize_t len_imported_names, PyObject *qualname, PyObject *moddict, int level); /*proto*/
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,8 +1,20 @@
-/////////////// Import.export ///////////////
+/////////////// Import.proto ///////////////////
 
 static PyObject *__Pyx_Import(PyObject *name, PyObject *const *imported_names, Py_ssize_t len_imported_names, PyObject *qualname, int level); /*proto*/
 
-/////////////// Import ///////////////
+/////////////// Import /////////////////////////
+//@requires: ImportImpl
+
+static PyObject *__Pyx_Import(PyObject *name, PyObject *const *imported_names, Py_ssize_t len_imported_names, PyObject *qualname, int level) {
+    // Forward to the shared utility code with an extra moddict argument (because that's not possible to look up in shared utility code)
+    return __Pyx__Import(name, imported_names, len_imported_names, qualname, level, NAMED_CGLOBAL(moddict_cname));
+}
+
+/////////////// ImportImpl.export ///////////////
+
+static PyObject *__Pyx__Import(PyObject *name, PyObject *const *imported_names, Py_ssize_t len_imported_names, PyObject *qualname, int level, PyObject *moddict); /*proto*/

comment_data.body: We should check this earlier, when _loading_ the utility code, to make sure we catch all errors, not just the ones that show in tests. It's generally fine for code that has an `.export` section to use `CGLOBAL()`, but at least the module specific names should be disallowed, as you suggest.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -823,6 +823,12 @@ def specialize(self, pyrex_type=None, **data):
 
             self.specialize_list.append(s)
             return s
+        
+    def _validate_suitable_for_sharing(self):
+        code_string = getattr(self, "impl")
+        if not code_string: return
+        assert "NAMED_CGLOBAL(moddict_cname)" not in code_string, \

@@ -1,8 +1,20 @@
-/////////////// Import.export ///////////////
+/////////////// Import.proto ///////////////////
 
 static PyObject *__Pyx_Import(PyObject *name, PyObject *const *imported_names, Py_ssize_t len_imported_names, PyObject *qualname, int level); /*proto*/
 
-/////////////// Import ///////////////
+/////////////// Import /////////////////////////
+//@requires: ImportImpl
+
+static PyObject *__Pyx_Import(PyObject *name, PyObject *const *imported_names, Py_ssize_t len_imported_names, PyObject *qualname, int level) {
+    // Forward to the shared utility code with an extra moddict argument (because that's not possible to look up in shared utility code)
+    return __Pyx__Import(name, imported_names, len_imported_names, qualname, level, NAMED_CGLOBAL(moddict_cname));
+}

comment_data.body: Just an idea: since it is just wrapping of other call cannot we declare the function as inline?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,8 +1,20 @@
-/////////////// Import.export ///////////////
+/////////////// Import.proto ///////////////////
 
 static PyObject *__Pyx_Import(PyObject *name, PyObject *const *imported_names, Py_ssize_t len_imported_names, PyObject *qualname, int level); /*proto*/
 
-/////////////// Import ///////////////
+/////////////// Import /////////////////////////
+//@requires: ImportImpl
+
+static PyObject *__Pyx_Import(PyObject *name, PyObject *const *imported_names, Py_ssize_t len_imported_names, PyObject *qualname, int level) {

comment_data.body: It would probably get inlined either way, but yes, if we expect it to be inlined then why not declare it as such.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,8 +1,20 @@
-/////////////// Import.export ///////////////
+/////////////// Import.proto ///////////////////
 
 static PyObject *__Pyx_Import(PyObject *name, PyObject *const *imported_names, Py_ssize_t len_imported_names, PyObject *qualname, int level); /*proto*/
 
-/////////////// Import ///////////////
+/////////////// Import /////////////////////////
+//@requires: ImportImpl
+
+static PyObject *__Pyx_Import(PyObject *name, PyObject *const *imported_names, Py_ssize_t len_imported_names, PyObject *qualname, int level) {

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
static CYTHON_INLINE PyObject *__Pyx_Import(PyObject *name, PyObject *const *imported_names, Py_ssize_t len_imported_names, PyObject *qualname, int level); /*proto*/
```

+/////////////// Import.proto ///////////////////

commit.message:
Fix shared relative import

The moddict must not come from the shared module.

Add test and validation that we don't make this mistake again.
undo my ongoing fight against code style
